"**Big Iron** " is a [country ballad](/wiki/Country_music "Country music")
written and performed by [Marty Robbins](/wiki/Marty_Robbins "Marty Robbins"),
originally released as an album track on _[Gunfighter Ballads and Trail
Songs](/wiki/Gunfighter_Ballads_and_Trail_Songs "Gunfighter Ballads and Trail
Songs")_ in September 1959, then as a single in February 1960 with the song
"Saddle Tramp" as the [B-side](/wiki/B-side "B-side") single. Members of the
[Western Writers of America](/wiki/Western_Writers_of_America "Western Writers
of America") chose it as one of the Top 100 Western songs of all time.[2]

It tells the story of an [Arizona Ranger](/wiki/Arizona_Rangers "Arizona
Rangers")'s duel with an outlaw named Texas Red in the "town of Agua Fria".[3]
The townspeople predict the death of the Ranger, Texas Red having already
killed "one and nineteen men", but the Ranger kills Texas Red with the
swiftness of the "big iron on his hip." This term refers to the gun the Ranger
carries. Texas Red hadn't even "cleared leather" \- the Ranger's draw was that
swift.

Robbins's version of the song reached #5 on the Billboard Country chart and
#26 on the [_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100")
chart in April 1960.[4]

The song is also featured in the video game _[Fallout: New
Vegas](/wiki/Fallout:_New_Vegas "Fallout: New Vegas")_ on the in-game radio,
Radio New Vegas.

The Ranger's "Big Iron" actually existed. It was a one-off custom handgun
chambered in [.45 Colt](/wiki/.45_Colt ".45 Colt") and featured a [Great
Western](/wiki/Great_Western_Arms_Company "Great Western Arms Company") copy
of the [Colt Single Action Army](/wiki/Colt_Single_Action_Army "Colt Single
Action Army") frame, [Colt 1860 Army](/wiki/Colt_Army_Model_1860 "Colt Army
Model 1860") backstrap, grip frame and grips and a cut down 9 1/2"
[Marlin](/wiki/Marlin_Firearms "Marlin Firearms") rifle barrel. Marty Robbins
saw it in Andy Anderson's famed North Hollywood gun shop in the late 1950s and
wrote the song around it. Its current whereabouts are unknown.[5]

## Cover versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Big_Iron&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cover versions")]

[Michael Martin Murphey](/wiki/Michael_Martin_Murphey "Michael Martin
Murphey") covered the song on his 1993 album _[Cowboy Songs
III](/wiki/Cowboy_Songs_III "Cowboy Songs III")_. With the Robbins family's
blessing, the song was recorded as a duet with Robbins. It was released as a
single and peaked at #62 on the _[RPM](/wiki/RPM_\(magazine\) "RPM
\(magazine\)")_ Country Tracks chart in Canada.[6]

Other covers of the song include:

  * _[Kingfish](/wiki/Kingfish_\(1976_album\) "Kingfish \(1976 album\)")_ (1976) by [Kingfish](/wiki/Kingfish_\(band\) "Kingfish \(band\)")
  * _[Under the Influences](/wiki/Under_the_Influences "Under the Influences")_ (1999) by [Mike Ness](/wiki/Mike_Ness "Mike Ness")
  * _Big Iron_ (2001) by [Carol Noonan](/wiki/Carol_Noonan "Carol Noonan")
  * _[Unearthed](/wiki/Unearthed_\(Johnny_Cash_album\) "Unearthed \(Johnny Cash album\)")_ (2003) by [Johnny Cash](/wiki/Johnny_Cash "Johnny Cash")
  * _Songs From The Mojave Wasteland_ (2010) soundtrack from [Fallout: New Vegas](/wiki/Fallout:_New_Vegas "Fallout: New Vegas")
